Elevated levels of strand breaks and diminished repair have been demonstrated in methylmethane sulphonate-treated x-ray repair cross-complementing group 1(-/-) cell lines compared  with wild-type cells [Horton et al., 2008]. Consistent with our results, introduction of the x-ray repair cross-complementing group 1 194Trp allele to x-ray repair cross-complementing group 1(-/-) cells fully restored the methylmethane sulphonate sensitivity as the wild-type allele, while the less common x-ray repair cross-complementing group 1 280His allele only partially restored the methylmethane sulphonate sensitivity and showed diminished initial repair as determined by the alkaline comet assay [Takanami et al., 2005]. Similarly, the x-ray repair cross-complementing group 1 399Gln allele complemented methylmethane sulphonate sensitivity of x-ray repair cross-complementing group 1-deficient cells, and reduced single-stranded breaks after a 3-hr repair incubation, equally well as the wild-type allele [Taylor et al., 2000]. The decreased repair observed at early time points after methylmethane sulphonate exposure in cells carrying the variant x-ray repair cross-complementing group 3 241Met allele is consistent with the previously reported association of the variant allele with a reduced repair of bulky DNA adducts [Matullo et al., 2001]. The initial lower repair in cells with the variant Nijmegen breakage syndrome 1 185Gln allele is in agreement with a recent study [Medina et al., 2003] in which homozygosity for this allele was associated with a significantly increased prevalence of p53 mutations in lung cancer patients. The apparently decreased damage, at subsequent later time points, in cell populations with the variant allele, could possibly be explained by formation of apoptotic cells due to overload of DNA damage in the repair-inefficient cells. Apoptotic cells were not scored in the present study. In conclusion, our results provide evidence for associations between gene variants in the base excision repair and homologous recombination repair pathways and altered repair efficiency following methylmethane sulphonate treatment, with a lower degree of repair in cells carrying the APEX1 Asp148 allele, the x-ray repair cross-complementing group 3 241Met allele or the Nijmegen breakage syndrome 1 185Gln allele.
